posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585565
>If I understand you correctly, that's just the reality of a system with such variation in mappers.
That's not really true, or at least it doesn't have to work that way. People hated on byuu for it but his cartridge folder format is perfect for something like this because it lets you define the cartridge PCB on a game by game basis. In the folder you'd have an XML that defines the PCB and then each chip would be it's own .ROM. This could just be zipped, too. This is what MAME does and it works perfectly. This way the emulator doesn't have to care about headers or formats. It can just be a base NES and the game itself informs the emulator what it's deal is. Without having to deal with headers you can "extend" the format infinitely large because each game defines itself, exactly like real carts do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585597
The schema for the XML would still need to be extended for every new chip that could be present in a PCB. It does sound a bit more flexible than the fixed size binary headers used in most ROM formats though.

Chilean here.

NEs piracy and Famiclones was everywhere in the nineties, yet the real/official NES market was particularly pretty strong in my country compared to other places in latin america.

SNES piracy was, at least until late nineties, kind of obscure. Sure we had piracy and some friends had bootleg cartridges of MK2 and DKC, but it was much more uncommon compared to the NES piracy. Most people here survived as SNES users thanks to rentals.

I've never, never heard about those copiers from Hong Kong until probably 1999 thanks to internet. I think those things would have been big if there were sold here.

PS1 piracy was basically the only way to play PS1 games here. Most PS1 users from latin america will tell you they never, ever saw any original game excluding demo discs and even some guys think that was "normal", like Sony sold you the console and you do the rest by yourself. I'm not joking.

There's semconflicting info in the manual and opening text. In her manual profile, it says that she's the "only survivor of her doomed home planet of Cerinia" and "roams the galaxy in search of answers." In the opening text, she "searches for the truth of her parents' death." Either way, she picks up a distress call in a small world in the Lylat system and investigates, the implication being that she has a feeling it's related to her troubles. You can infer that Cerinia was outside Lylat, she was orphaned recently, Andross had something to do with it and lured her, she dresses in a manner that's not unusual on her home planet, and that ship she used to board the Great Fox was probably how she initially arrived on the planet....
....and since absolutely none of that was followed through in the slightest, the Japanese version apparently cuts any and all mention of Cerinia or her parents, and doesn't even subtitle the line suggesting she might've recognized Andross, so she in the Japanese version has even less nuggets of back-story and is a totally random scantily clad blue adventurer.

>>9555378
That's entirely on Nintendo of America.

By the time Super Bomberman 3 released in Japan, Hudson Soft USA was closed and had to cancel localizations for Super Bonk 2 and Elfaria (possibly in collaboration with Working Designs, but Hudson would still publish)

Nintendo chose to pick up Super Bomberman 3 and Nintendo of America staff worked on the localization and game testing (there's even footage in a Japanese documentary) much like with Terranigma, they just chose to release it only in Europe.

It's not too weird, because NoE was still a subsidary of NoA and translators were really discouraged from learning Japanese directly (not that it kept them from doing it anyways, and the Japanese staff from appreciating it, and for them to eventually get their autonomy to reduce the +1 year release schedule gaps), but Nintendo of America's weird insistence on killing the SNES as soon as 1995 was something. Metal Warriors by LucasArts was supposed to be a Nintendo-published game too, and they planned an English localization of DBZ Super Butoden 2 (simply called Dragon Ball) in 1996 meant for Mexican audiences.

>>9555689
Scandinavia has its own Nintendo distribution. When Nintendo was busy getting fucked over by Atari (failed 1983 American Famicom launch as rebranded Atari, Atari intended to bury Nintendo alive by sitting on the rights all along, Nintendo headhunted some of those Atari marketing teams and tried to slowly piece together its own distribution) and Mattel/Bandai (European distribution until 1993), the Scandinavian branch was the only one actually doing its job, and even getting titles sooner than other regions.

>>9560310
Some of these weird regional releases for the Sega Megadrive are games planned for the USA then cancelled. Things that immediately come to mind is Maui Mallard in Cold Shadow - an NTSC version of the Sega Genesis version exists with improvements and changes, but Nintendo secured exclusivity for the game in that region, so that ended up releasing only in Brazil.

A Daze in Christmas was also formally cancelled after being rushed for release, but some copies were already ordered for manufacturing so they ended up selling them in Australia anyways.

>>9557474
and this. This one only sold in Spain, and only had a Spanish manual. That told people to get an English speaker to translate the ingame text for them. The cover artist was known for other American-region cover art. It's completely unoptimized for PAL regions too.

>>9559062
There's a weird sub-series on the GBA and DS by Takara Tomy that Nintendo of Europe picked publishing for halfway through the series and pretended one of those game was the first in the series, but the "European Version".
Then Takara Tomy continued to release the next games with the wrong order in Europe as "European Versions", and somehow Europe ended up with a game that never got released in the USA (but the localization quality was horrible, Terranigma tier fonts and SNK quality translations)

>>9570083
Nah, the USA got the first game.
I'll explain.

IE1 (DS) and IE3 (DS) are Japan exclusive
Europe got IE2 (DS) twice, the first time was called IE1 with the story/moves swapped with the second game's campaign mode. That's why the Layton team isn't present.

IE1, IE2, IE3 were remade true to their original gameplay/content, for the 3DS.
This collection never released in the West intact, but some parts of it did as standalone games:
IE3 (3DS) was Europe exclusive as usual
IE1 (3DS) was America exclusive digital release, with the European loc poorly copy pasted and referencing IE2 content.
IE2 (3DS) was cancelled alongside Go Galaxy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9555090
Gran Turismo Concept (a spinoff/companion game to GT3) had quite a few releases, but no true version ever reached the States. It was initially released in Japan, then in South Korea where more cars got added (Hyundai obviously), then in Europe where even more were added. Instead, the US got a simplified demo intended for a press kit that only lets you use a Nissan 350Z Concept car on one track for 150 seconds, but it turns out that all the files for the full game are merely hidden, and a homebrew US version can be made by altering some config files. Interestingly, among the cut content in the files, there exists a motorcycle bearing the Tourist Trophy logo 3 years before that game came out, and a Mini Cooper S rally car that never appeared again.

—I’d like to ask a bit about the environment you played in. Looking at the picture you shared with us, it looks like you sat with your legs crossed while you played?

MON: Yes, that’s how I played.
—Sitting cross-legged like that and playing for a long time, didn’t your legs start to hurt or get numb?

MON: In my case, that didn’t happen.
—Did you choose that posture because playing on an arcade cabinet with your elbows bent is straining, but sitting cross-legged like this allowed you to keep them straight?

MON: No, that wasn’t it. I find playing on an arcade cabinet very easy, and it's the standard for me. I just found the cross-legged posture the easiest way to emulate that.
—I see you play on a tate’d CRT…

MON: I do pretty much all my gaming on a CRT.
—Right, HD TVs still have problems with screen lag/delay.

MON: Yeah. Especially with the 2nd loop of Death Label, there’s parts where the speed of your reaction time is being pushed to the limit, so you want to minimize any display lag.
MON’s setup.
—I noticed your joystick there is the HORI Real Arcade Pro. Have you made any modifications to it?

MON: I’ve made one small adjustment, actually. Not with the electronics, but I adjusted the microswitches to change the play in the stick by adding spacers.
—Was this to reduce the play in the stick?

MON: Not necessarily… there’s still some play there. It was just to make it easier for me personally. (laughs)
—Did you swap out the buttons or the stick itself?

MON: No, I didn’t change anything there.
—That’s somewhat unusual.

MON: It's often said among gamers that “the best stick for STG is Seimitsu, and the best for fighting games is Sanwa.” But personally, I think that in the end whatever is easiest for you to control is best. So this time I used a Sanwa stick.

im not an expert or autist, so details like minor delay or run ahead dont mean shit to me. all the arcade ports ive played on ps2 i cant fault,

apparently the cave ports on ps2 r some of the best compared to the steam pc ports, tho i did read that on reddit.

the benefit of using a ps2 is its a lot easier to plug into a crt, a lot of the games are considered to be arcade perfect ports, especially certain SNK games, ive stuck a bunch on internal hdd and load with openloader, its simple AF.

emulation thru mame is obviously, the top choice if ur using a pc, connecting it to a crt can be a headache as you have to play with custom drivers/ resolutions/ refresh rates just to get ur picture right, if ur rotating the screen as well, much more hassle to set up. i know the CAVE shmups in mame need at least a core2duo to run full speed, so anything less powerful like a raspberry pi might not be up to the job,

i'd like to have my pc connected to a tate crt, but the ps2 is just as good as it covers all the important arcade games from 1978 upwards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: How do you feel about save states?
posts.com:
I know that save states are a classic topic of discussion on /vr/ due to being somewhat controversial, with the main argument against them being that their use is cheating and therefore takes away the legitimacy of one's run, and I have to agree, you're not truly beating the video game you used save states on, it wasn't the intended experience by the developers. However, one can use save states in many different ways and I believe some qualify more as cheating than others, and in the end there's always another topic of discussion, and that is if the fact that it's cheating matters more than one's enjoyment. Anyways, save states are used for a variety of reasons:

1. Save whenever faced with an obstacle so that you take no damage at all.
2. Save only at the start of a level to replicate unlimited continues and avoiding getting sent back to the beggining.
3. Save only so that you don't have to input a long password every single time you come back to your run.
4. Save only when you absolutely must leave and want to pick up from where you left off.

Of course there are more uses, but these are the main ones I can think off. I used to do #1 when I got into emulation as a kid, but eventually it got shallow and I stopped. I'll only do #3 if the passwords are long, because in general I love inputting them. I've never used #4. However, #2 is the most interesting to me, and from my experience it can improve the experience, depending on what you're playing. If I'm playing something really good, then I don't mind getting sent back to the begging, because the early stages are fun, but if I'm playing something mediocre or bad, I feel that recreating unlimited continues through save states is better than quitting altogether.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The simple and obvious answer is: no.
Reason:
They are not used by the highest level players.
If there was an advantage to using them then the top players would be using them.
They were experimented with years ago and most reports indicated no difference in winning or scoring, or inferior performance to the standard buttons.

Now, is is possible the winds could shift and if someone uses them to get a big win or a world record opinions could change.
But these buttons have been around for decades now and that hasn't happened.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9583286
The short answer is yes, the long answer is kind of. As far as buttons go, just within the conventional Sanwa stuff there's the foam pads, which change the travel and make the bottom mushy but do a good job of turning that plastic smacking into a quieter thud, and the elastomer cap style which have pretty much normal travel but are a grippier material I don't love and seem to mostly turn high pitched noises into lower pitched noises rather than being massively quieter overall. Maybe in a case with less echo it would work better, I don't know. There's a bunch of other meme options with silent keyboard switches and silicon inserts and shit as well.

Joysticks you can just flat out get non-clicking switches and only have the low pitched gate thud but the feel is different and the prices are kind of nuts. I've never bothered because ultimately the joystick isn't any louder than silenced buttons. The standard there is Hayabusa silent (I don't think you can buy them separately from a full silent Hori stick), and silent JLF high tension, but if I was buying one I'd be trying the LSQ-40.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9584327
>What changed from their usual plastic that the translucent ones that makes a different sound profile? It seemed the same for me on the outside.

The plungers are comprised of three parts with some play between them as opposed to just one solid piece of plastic like in the opaque models. When fully assembled you can even twist the translucent color top cap back and forth quite a bit. So not only do they sound rattly, they feel like it too. You can try this for yourself. Take out on of these plungers like pic related, hold it by the lower white part and then hit it like you wanted to activate the button. Now do the same with an opaque model. They're fucking ass and feel and sound so unsatisfying to play on. Switching out the plungers for opaque ones was the first mod I did right after I bought a stick that came with these pre-installed because I was so disappointed with them. The housing is fine however. It's really just the way the plungers are constructed that makes them terrible. An easy fix in the end.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9584327
Holding them in my hands again now, I have to say that I was actually too lax in my original post. The problem isn't only present when bottoming out. These buttons rattle if you so much as look at them. It gets a little better if you take the insert out from under the top cap but then you can see the little radial beam construction underneath and the loose top cap still remains somewhat annoying to me. If one really wants these for aesthetic reasons I would suggest taking them apart and carefully super glueing all the parts together. I imagine that would help quite a bit.

>>9586139
Ausjank. Also there's a funny story from the lead programmer, Andrew Davie.

>While we were testing [The Three Stooges] we had a problem with the sprites glitching. Took us a while to realize that the OAM table was _dynamic_ RAM. Now, TTS was a very stingy game that only updated the OAM every couple of frames. What was happening was the NES we were using, at least the particular revision we had, when the PPU would warm up, the OAM decay kept getting shorter and shorter. If I sprayed the PPU with a can of freeze spray to cool it off, the sprites would quit glitching. However, we did eventually modify the game code to go easier on the machine.

>>9569323
I'll try my best to explain what the fuck is really going on here.

One year before Metroid's release in 1985 the Dirty Pair television series aired on Japanese TV. During this time period science fiction in general was experiencing a boom on account of Return of the Jedi releasing just a few years prior.

Samus's helmet and her profession, intergalactic bounty hunter, were clearly inspired by Boba Fett. (Just one of the many references, like Ridley being named after the director of Aliens.)

As for her unarmored form, it was inspired by Yuri from Dirty Pair, a series whose popularity at the time could not be overstated. Dirty Pair was everywhere during that time period and had many copycats and references. In fact, Time Gal, lifts the design wholesale.

But Samus's unarmored form was only really supposed to be an easter egg for players skilled enough to complete the game in time. There wasn't much more thought to it beyond that and its design was based on the most popular female design of the time period.

Most people weren't even aware that Samus was female until the late 90s. They just assumed the person you played as was a guy.

The author of this article seems to have done more actual research into this than anyone:
https://www.acriticalhit.com/metroids-justin-bailey-is-a-real-person-heres-why-he-hasnt-spoken-up/

His conclusion is that Justin Bailey was probably a random player of the game who input their own name for the hell of it, followed by a row of dashes, and it JUST HAPPENED to register as a functional password with a bunch of shit unlocked, including the New Game+ alternate suit.

This seems like a rather remarkable set of coincidences, these games usually have some sort of checksum integrated into the password so inputting just anything won't work, and the fact this just happens to work with two six-character names and a row of plain dashes should be investigated to see just how likely any random password--no, not random, any password containing names and aesthetic repeating characters--is to be both valid and full of ingame goodies. Then, you'd have to have this mysterious Justin Bailey kid sending a letter to some gaming mag about the great password, but neglect to mention that it's actually his own name, or the magazine reprints it without this information and "makes up" the "just in bailey" rumor. The author suggests the "real" "Justin Bailey" may have been a 2-year old child at the time and a friend or family member just tried every name they new until one registered. All seems kinda sus IMO.

>but you always shoot whatever is in front of you regardless of elevation
Absolute bullshit repeated by retards. Dooms projectiles operate in 3d space.

[code]

//
// P_SpawnPlayerMissile
// Tries to aim at a nearby monster
//
void
P_SpawnPlayerMissile
( mobj_t* source,
mobjtype_t type )
{
mobj_t* th;
angle_t an;

fixed_t x;
fixed_t y;
fixed_t z;
fixed_t slope;

// see which target is to be aimed at
an = source->angle;
slope = P_AimLineAttack (source, an, 16*64*FRACUNIT);

if (!linetarget)
{
an += 1<<26;
slope = P_AimLineAttack (source, an, 16*64*FRACUNIT);

if (!linetarget)
{
an -= 2<<26;
slope = P_AimLineAttack (source, an, 16*64*FRACUNIT);
}

if (!linetarget)
{
an = source->angle;
slope = 0;
}
}

x = source->x;
y = source->y;
z = source->z + 4*8*FRACUNIT;

th = P_SpawnMobj (x,y,z, type);

if (th->info->seesound)
S_StartSound (th, th->info->seesound);

th->target = source;
th->angle = an;
th->momx = FixedMul( th->info->speed,
finecosine[an>>ANGLETOFINESHIFT]);
th->momy = FixedMul( th->info->speed,
finesine[an>>ANGLETOFINESHIFT]);
th->momz = FixedMul( th->info->speed, slope);

P_CheckMissileSpawn (th);
}


[/code]

See all those z calculations? Looks pretty 2d to me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
it's weird to explain. but in short doom is a 3D game. though the way the original game was rendered is very different from how games after were rendered. it used two things that were uniquely strange.

first was the sector mapping system. modern engines create maps with a collection 3D meshes. doom had rooms as a single polygon called a sector and polygonal edges were called linedefs. each sector had it's own floor/ceiling height, lighting and textures assignment. adjacent sectors that shared vertices, points on the polygon, would appear as connected rooms with no wall between them.

second was how it was rendered. it used something called raycast. where the player cast a number of 2D rays out into the sector which would continue until they hit a linedef. if that linedef was a connected sector then the ray would continue through the adjacent sector. repeats until it hits a valid wall to render. it would then render the wall/ceiling/floor, in a single vertical slice that was 1 pixel wide. and the number of rays cast were the width of the screen. like 320x240 would cast 320 rays to fill the screen with vertical slices.

another weird thing was how the game played. which was basically a top down game, like the map view. this has been corrected in modern engines. but in the original doom the verticality of your aim was ignored. the only time height was a factor were in player collisions. making unreachable areas above you with walls you can't surmount. and this can be disabled with noclip

one of my favorite features of using the system created for doom was that levels didn't have to abide by the rules of Euclidian geometry. connected sectors could loop back into themselves and never intersect because of the way the game renders.

bisquit has a great video on the subject. jump to 13:42 for a view into how Doom's renderer works.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HQYsFshbkYw&t=822s

Doom is a textbook example of a 2D plane being projected into 3D space.
The maps are 2D, the game itself is 3D, the ability to have room over room or object over object is not what makes it 3D.
3D just needs movement in all 3 axis, which Doom has.
Wolfenstein is not 3D, Doom is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9583970
>doom had rooms as a single polygon called a sector and polygonal edges were called linedefs
Sort of, a sector is just a space with defined heights, lighting, effect, tags, and flats (floor or ceiling textures, including one which will render the sky texture when used). A room can be a single sector, but often they aren't, instead making up multiple.
If you look at a set of stairs, every step on that stair is its own sector with its own defined height.

>second was how it was rendered. it used something called raycast. where the player cast a number of 2D rays out into the sector which would continue until they hit a linedef. if that linedef was a connected sector then the ray would continue through the adjacent sector. repeats until it hits a valid wall to render. it would then render the wall/ceiling/floor, in a single vertical slice that was 1 pixel wide. and the number of rays cast were the width of the screen. like 320x240 would cast 320 rays to fill the screen with vertical slices.
Doom doesn't raycast, it uses Binary Space Partitioning to cut the level up into chunks and then determines what gets rendered or not from what position.

>>9584473
Doom does, because it's 3D.

>>9586134
>Quake netplay was way more influential

OpenGL wouldn't be as big as it is without Qjuake and Quake II. Granted, OpenGL wasn't part of the original release of Quake I. The MiniGL patch was released 6-8 months later, or something. But the MiniGL patch did convince companies like Nvidia, ATi, 3DFX and other videocard developers to patch OpenGL into their drivers. Quake II came with OpenGL right out of the box. Granted, The Khronos Group have moved on to Vulkan. But OpenGL is still pretty widely used today. ID Software did not create OpenGL, it was available for things like Windows NT. But ID helped port OpenGL to the Windows9X kernel, which was adopted as an industry standard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9585008
Quake was more revolutionary. A fully 3d fps with online deathmatch was huge. It was the beginning of e-sports. It was one of the first FPS games to have multiplayer-only maps. Quake demos helped establish speedrunning as a thing. Quake pushed people to upgrade their computers, a much more popular platform than the N64. The code had such a legacy that even Half-Life 2 has some Quake code in it.

As for which aged better visually, most people probably prefer the more varied color palette of Mario 64. As for level design, Mario levels feel like a bunch of bunch of abstract block combinations, compared to Quake levels, which feel more realistic and cohesive, each with plenty of secrets and even 4 secret levels. Quake has better enemies, but I would expect it to, since it's a different genre. As for atmosphere, Mario has a fairly light and varied atmosphere, compared to the neverending darkness of Quake. Quake is significantly more replayable because of the higher difficulty ceiling, online multiplayer, and mods. As for gameplay, they're both near the apex of their genres, the 3d platformer and the boomer shooter, and you're free to prefer either.

Graphics have gotten better in both genres, and both the 3d platformer and FPS genres have undergone changes, but I see a lot of FPS fans who want to go back to the good old days of FPS when games like Blood and Quake were new. I don't think fans of 3d platformers want the genre to regress -- they're happy with the improvements made by Mario Galaxy and Mario Odyssey. So I suppose Mario 64 has aged worse, since while people like it, people want to move on from it to newer and better things, which is not something you can say of Quake, what with the interest in returning to the past with retro-style boomer shooters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They were hugely influential in different ways.

SM64 proved that 2D games could make the jump to 3D and still be great or even better than they used to be. This used to be a major concern because most attempts to make existing game franchises 3D were lackluster or difficult to control. It also showed how important an analog stick was.
Quake's rendering and movement controls were so influential to shooters that most games just copied the code. It also showed devs that they could push the limits of PC technology and customers would upgrade their computers just to play games, something that console owners rarely ever did as most expansion hardware showed.

Chamber of Secrets on Gameboy Color is one of the best RPGs for the Gameboy. Griptonite, the studio that developed this, was one of the most underrated devs out there. Now they just do mobile thrash.

Jeremy Soule's soundtrack for the first games is overall incredible.
